message_1: A sample of radium-226 has an initial activity of 10,000 disintegrations per second. Calculate the activity of the sample after 12 days, given that the half-life of radium-226 is 1602 years.
message_2:
To calculate the activity of the sample after 12 days, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

First, we need to convert the half-life of radium-226 from years to seconds and the time elapsed from days to seconds.

1 year = 365.25 days (accounting for leap years)
1 day = 24 hours
1 hour = 60 minutes
1 minute = 60 seconds

Half-life in seconds:
1602 years * 365.25 days/year * 24 hours/day * 60 minutes/hour * 60 seconds/minute ≈ 5.058e+10 seconds

Time elapsed in seconds:
12 days * 24 hours/day * 60 minutes/hour * 60 seconds/minute = 1,036,800 seconds

Now we can plug these values into the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = 10,000 disintegrations/second * (1/2)^(1,036,800 seconds / 5.058e+10 seconds)

Activity_final ≈ 10,000 disintegrations/second * (1/2)^0.0205
Activity_final ≈ 10,000 disintegrations/second * 0.9803
Activity_final ≈ 9,803 disintegrations/second

The activity of the radium-226 sample after 12 days is approximately 9,803 disintegrations per second.
